title: Another Oscars blunder: In Memoriam segment pays tribute to 'alive and well' producer Jan Chapman
text:
Another Oscars blunder: In Memoriam segment pays tribute to 'alive and well' producer Jan Chapman Sara Bareilles performs during an In Memoriam tribute at the Oscars Credit: Chris Pizzello/Invision/AP Adam Boult  38am 
T he 2017 Academy Awards will most likely be remembered for one almighty gaffe - Warren Beatty wrongly announcing La La Land as Best Picture winner over the actual winner, Moonlight. 
However, another significant blunder has also emerged. During the In Memoriam segment, in which the Academy pays tribute to figures from the film world who have died over the previous 12 months, a photo of a still-living film producer was accidentally included. 
The image of Australian producer Jan Chapman appeared in the montage film, with accompanying text naming costume designer Janet Patterson, who died in October 2016. hey @TheAcademy you need to pull this and replace with a photo of Janet Patterson, not very much alive Jan Chapman https://t.co/REY9xRh8Cb — palace films (@palacefilms) 27 February 2017 
M s Patterson was previously nominated for four Oscars , for her work on The Piano, Portrait of a Lady, Oscar and Lucinda and Bright Star. 
Ms Chapman, who had worked on Bright Star and The Piano with Ms Patterson, told Variety she was "devastated" by the error saying: “I am alive and well and an active producer.” This came up in the In Memoriam section at #Oscars2017 . But isn't this (living) Australian film producer Jan Chapman? pic.twitter.com/YKIMGBUv5E — David Berthold (@DavidBerthold) 27 February 2017 
“I was devastated by the use of my image in place of my great friend and long-time collaborator Janet Patterson. I had urged her agency to check any photograph which might be used and understand that they were told that the Academy had it covered. Janet was a great beauty and four-time Oscar nominee and it is very disappointing that the error was not picked up.” 
T he In Memoriam tribute film featured stars including Carrie Fisher, Prince, and Debbie Reynolds, and was accompanied by a performance of the Joni Mitchell song Both Sides Now by award-winning singer-songwriter Sara Bareilles. Watch | Oscars 2017 highlights
